newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks dip to close down.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks dip to close down.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Tuesday after a late afternoon slide trade which brokers described as a short bout of overdue profit-taking.
"This market was long overdue for a short-term correction, said Francis Wong, head of regional sales at DBS Securities.
The Hang Seng Index shed 65.39 points to 12,444.66 after trending sideways on robust volume during the morning session.
Trading was active all day, bringing turnover to HK$7.30 billion, greater than Friday's HK$6.67 billion.
But brokers said they thought selling would be limited.
Wong of DBS said the sellers in the market both those shedding long-term positions and those taking short-term trading gains.
"While we saw some lock in profits today, locally based funds are not selling because the property market outlook is improving," said Patrick Ho, sales director at UBS Securities.
"They will continue to hold onto their (equity market) positions if they think the property market improvements are going to flow back to the market," Ho said.
Technical analysts were cautious on the short-term outlook for the market.
"Indicators on the daily chart, the RSI and MACD have turned bearish," said Ted Chen, technical analyst at Technical Data Inc.
"In the short term we are running into resistance at 12,600. The market is very overbought and we are likely to see limited upside for the remainder of the week," he said.
Chen puts minor support at 12,300 and major support at 11,900.
The property sector managed to fare the best in the afternoon sell-off, while the commercial and industrial sector bore the brunt of the heaviest profit-taking.
